{{Use mdy dates|date=July 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Morey Amsterdam | image = Morey Amsterdam HA-SN-99-00637.jpg | caption = Morey Amsterdam in 1970 | birth_name = Moritz Amsterdam | birth_date = {{Birth date|1908|12|14}} | birth_place = [[Chicago, Illinois|Chicago]], [[Illinois]], [[United States|U.S.]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1996|10|27|1908|12|14}} | death_place = [[Los Angeles, California|Los Angeles]], [[California]], U.S. | death_cause = [[Myocardial infarction|Heart attack]] | resting_place = [[Forest Lawn Memorial Park (Hollywood Hills)|Forest Lawn Memorial Park Cemetery]] in [[Hollywood Hills, California|Hollywood Hills]], California | occupation = Actor, comedian | yearsactive = 1922–1996 | spouse = {{marriage|Mabel Todd|1933|1945}}
{{marriage|Kay Patrick|1949}} | children = Gregory and Cathy Amsterdam }} '''Moritz "Morey" Amsterdam''' (December 14, 1908 – October 27, 1996) was an American television actor and comedian. He was known for the role of Buddy Sorrell on [[CBS]]'s ''[[The Dick Van Dyke Show]]'' from 1961 to 1966.{{cite news |author=[[David Stout]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/29/arts/morey-amsterdam-comedian-and-joke-encyclopedia-dies.html |title=Morey Amsterdam, Comedian and Joke Encyclopedia, Dies |quote=Morey Amsterdam ... died on Monday in Los Angeles. He was in his 80's. Mr. Amsterdam suffered a heart attack at his home and died at Cedars Sinai Hospital ... |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=October 29, 1996 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151218152158/https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/29/arts/morey-amsterdam-comedian-and-joke-encyclopedia-dies.html |archive-date=December 18, 2015 |dead-url=no |accessdate=August 29, 2012 }} ==Early life== Amsterdam was born in [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]], the youngest of the three sons of Max and Jennie (Finder) Amsterdam, [[Jew]]ish immigrants from [[Austria-Hungary]].Some biographies list him as born in [[San Francisco]] because his father was a violinist with the [[San Francisco Symphony]]. He began working in [[vaudeville]] in 1922 as the [[straight man]] for his older brother's jokes. He was a [[cello|cellist]], a skill he used throughout his career. By 1924, he was working in a [[speakeasy]] operated by [[Al Capone]]. After being caught in the middle of a gunfight, Amsterdam moved to [[California]] and worked writing jokes. His enormous repertoire, and his ability to come up with a joke on any subject, earned him the nickname '''The Human Joke Machine'''. He sometimes performed with a mock machine on his chest, hanging by a strap. He turned a hand crank and paper rolled out; he would then pretend to read the machine's joke, although actually the paper was blank. Amsterdam's reputation for humor preceded him. [[Hal Block]] tells of Amsterdam walking up Sixth Avenue in [[New York City]] and meeting an old friend. "Where have you been?" the friend asked. "Sick," Amsterdam replied, "I've been in bed with a cold." His friend looked at him and asked, "What's so funny about that?"{{Cite news|newspaper=The Milwaukee Journal (republished from ''Collier's'')| date=October 18, 1950| page=M24|last=Block| first=Hal| title=A Comic's Life Isn't Funny}} ==Radio, songwriting and screenwriting== {{Unreferenced section|date=September 2010}} During the 1930s, Amsterdam was a regular on ''[[Al Pearce|The Al Pearce Show]]'' radio program, and by 1937 was the master of ceremonies on ''The Night Club of the Air''. Amsterdam also had a notable career as a songwriter, with his first popular success being "Why Oh Why Did I Ever Leave Wyoming". Amsterdam was credited as the lyricist on the 1945 [[Andrews Sisters]] hit "[[Rum and Coca-Cola]]". However, the original song was written and performed by Trinidadian calypso singer [[Lord Invader]], and composed by [[Lionel Belasco]]. Amsterdam had altered some lyrics for the Andrews Sisters record, and was subsequently involved in a copyright suit over the song, which dragged on until 1948. In the end, Lord Invader was given a substantial royalty payment for having written the lyrics of original piece, while Amsterdam retained the credit (and the publishing rights) for his revised version of the lyric. In the early 1940s, Amsterdam was a screenwriter, contributing dialogue for two [[East Side Kids]] films. He is listed as screenwriter for the 1943 film ''[[The Ghost and the Guest]]'' and 1944's ''[[Bowery Champs]]''. By 1947, he was performing on three daily radio shows. Beginning in 1948, he appeared on the radio show ''[[Stop Me If You've Heard This One]]''. ''[[The Morey Amsterdam Show]]'' aired on [[CBS]] radio from July 10, 1948, to February 15, 1949. For three months, it was on both radio and television with different scripts for the same premise and cast. He also did a radio show called the ''Laugh and Swing Club'', broadcasting from the Filmart Theater on Vine Street in Hollywood, in the late 1940s and early 1950s. ==Television== [[File:Morey amsterdam WNBTshow bookmark promotion.jpg|thumb|left|80px|Bookmark promotion for Amsterdam's late night NBC show.]] ''[[The Morey Amsterdam Show]]'' ran on CBS TV from December 1948 to March 1949 and on [[DuMont Television Network|DuMont]] from April 1949 to October 1950. Among Morey's regular guests was song-and-dance man [[Art Carney]]. The cigarette girl was future author [[Jacqueline Susann]], wife of the producer of the show, [[Irving Mansfield]]. {{Citation needed|date=September 2010}} Jazz musician [[Johnny Guarnieri|Johnny Guarneri]] led the band. In 1950, he briefly hosted the comedy-variety show ''[[Broadway Open House]]'', TV's first late-night entertainment show, on [[NBC]]. One of the pioneering TV creations of NBC president [[Sylvester "Pat" Weaver|Pat Weaver]], it demonstrated the potential for late-night programming and led to the later development of ''[[The Tonight Show]]''.McNeil, Alex. ''Total Television: a Comprehensive Guide to Programming from 1948 to the Present''. Penguin, 1985. The show was originally to be hosted by comic [[Don Hornsby|Don "Creesh" Hornsby]] (so nicknamed because he yelled "Creesh" often), but he died of [[polio]] two weeks before the premiere broadcast. Hornsby's replacements, hosting different nights each week, were Amsterdam (Monday and Wednesday) and the raucous [[Jerry Lester]] (Tuesdays, Thursdays and Fridays), the brother of character actor [[Buddy Lester]]. Amsterdam soon exited the show, leaving Lester the sole host.{{citation needed|date=January 2018}} In February 1952, Amsterdam made his dramatic TV debut on an episode of the DuMont Television Network series ''[[Not for Publication (DuMont TV series)|Not for Publication]]''.{{cite book|title=[[The Complete Directory to Prime Time Network and Cable TV Shows, 1946-Present]]|year=2003|publisher=Ballantine Books|isbn=0-345-45542-8|pages=866}} In 1957, he appeared as "Jack Connors" in the third episode ("The Three Pretenders") of the [[Television syndication|syndicated]] television [[sitcom]] ''[[How to Marry a Millionaire (TV series)|How to Marry a Millionaire]]'', with [[Barbara Eden]] and [[Merry Anders]].{{cite web|title=How to Marry a Millionaire: The Three Pretenders|work=[[Internet Movie Database]]|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0606170|accessdate=November 18, 2017}} [[File:Dick van dyke show 1962.JPG|thumb|180px|Amsterdam as Buddy, in this episode the house guest of Rob and Laura Petrie on ''[[The Dick Van Dyke Show]]'' (1962)]] In 1958, he appeared as saloon manager Lucien Bellingham in an episode of the CBS [[Western (genre)|western]] series ''[[Have Gun, Will Travel]]'' entitled "The Moor's Revenge". He later guest-starred on the CBS sitcom ''[[Pete and Gladys]]'', with [[Harry Morgan]] and [[Cara Williams]]. His best-known role was as comedy writer Buddy Sorrell on ''[[The Dick Van Dyke Show]]'', a role suggested for him by his friend [[Rose Marie]], who also appeared on the show.{{cite book|last=Waldron|first=Vince|title=The Official Dick Van Dyke Show Book|publisher=Chicago Review Press|edition=3|year=2011|location=Chicago|pages=51–52|isbn=978-1-56976-839-6}} The show's creator, [[Carl Reiner]], based the character on his old friend [[Mel Brooks]], with whom he worked on the writing staff of ''[[Your Show of Shows]]''. Like Amsterdam himself, Buddy had a ready quip for any situation, and one of the show's most popular running gags was his insult-laden feud with producer Mel Cooley ([[Richard Deacon (actor)|Richard Deacon]]). Buddy was also one of the rare overtly Jewish characters on TV in that era, with one episode revolving around his belated decision to have a Bar Mitzvah. Amsterdam also wrote lyrics for the show's theme song, which were never heard on the air, but have been performed by [[Dick Van Dyke]] in concert.{{cite book|last=Waldron|first=Vince|title=The Official Dick Van Dyke Show Book|publisher=Chicago Review Press|edition=3|year=2011|location=Chicago|page=379|isbn=978-1-56976-839-6}} Van Dyke sang those lyrics on the October 23, 2010 edition of the NPR show ''[[Wait Wait... Don't Tell Me!]]''.Available as transcript and audio [https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=130739954 WWDTM 10-23-10], npr.org; accessed January 8, 2018. Amsterdam was an occasional panelist on ''[[Match Game]]'' and the short-lived ''[[Can You Top This?]]'' (which he also executive produced) during the 1970s. He appeared as a small-time criminal in several episodes of the soap opera ''[[The Young and the Restless]]'' in the 1990s. Amsterdam and Rose Marie later appeared as panelists on ''[[The Hollywood Squares]]'' and guest-starred together in a February 1996 episode of the NBC sitcom ''[[Caroline in the City]]'' (his final TV appearance).{{Cite web|url=http://www.imdb.com/name/nm0025440/|title=Morey Amsterdam|website=IMDb|access-date=2018-09-23}} ==Films== {{Unreferenced section|date=September 2010}} [[File:Morey Amsterdam handprints.jpg|thumb|150px|The handprints of Morey Amsterdam in front of Theater of the Stars at [[Walt Disney World]]'s [[Disney's Hollywood Studios]] theme park]] In 1958, Amsterdam appeared in the low-budget film ''[[Machine-Gun Kelly (film)|Machine-Gun Kelly]]'' with [[Charles Bronson]], and he did a notable dramatic turn in the 1960 noir classic ''[[Murder, Inc. (1960 film)|Murder, Inc.]]'' as Catskill nightclub owner Walter Sage, the first victim (according to the film) of the newly minted Murder, Incorporated. Amsterdam played Cappy, owner of the local nightclub, in the ''[[Beach Party]]'' movies of the 1960s, which were produced by [[American International Pictures]], of which he was vice president.{{Cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/local/obituaries/archives/la-me-morey-amsterdam-19961029-snap-20161027-story.html|title=From the Archives: Morey Amsterdam; 'Buddy' on 'Dick Van Dyke Show' - Los Angeles Times|last=Writer|first=Myrna Oliver, Times Staff|website=latimes.com|access-date=2018-09-23}} He and Rose Marie also co-starred in the 1966 film, ''[[Don't Worry, We'll Think of a Title]]'', a comedy co-written and co-produced by Amsterdam. The film features [[Richard Deacon (actor)|Richard Deacon]], their co-star on ''The Dick Van Dyke Show'', with [[cameo appearance|cameos]] by the show's co-producer [[Danny Thomas]] and co-star [[Carl Reiner]]. His later roles included appearances in ''[[The Horse in the Gray Flannel Suit]]'' (1968), ''[[Won Ton Ton, the Dog Who Saved Hollywood]]'' (1976), ''[[When Nature Calls]]'' (1985) and ''Side by Side'' (1988). ==Death== Amsterdam died of a [[myocardial infarction|heart attack]] at [[Cedars Sinai Hospital]] in [[Los Angeles, California|Los Angeles]], California, on October 27, 1996, at the age of 87.Vallance, Tom, [https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/obituary-morey-amsterdam-1350735.html "Obituary: Morey Amsterdam "], ''[[The Independent]]'' (London), November 4, 1996. Retrieved October 6, 2010 He was survived by his wife Kay Patrick and their children, Gregory and Catherine. He was entombed at [[Forest Lawn Memorial Park (Hollywood Hills)|Forest Lawn - Hollywood Hills Cemetery]] in Los Angeles. ==Further reading== * ''Keep Laughing.'' Citadel Press, 1959. ASIN B0007E665M * ''Morey Amsterdam's Benny Cooker Crock Book for Drinkers.'' Regnery, 1977. {{ISBN|0-8092-8138-4}} {{Portal|Biography|Chicago|Illinois|New York City|Los Angeles|California|Comedy|Radio|Music|Film|Television|Judaism}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category}} * {{IMDb name|0025440}} * [http://movies2.nytimes.com/gst/movies/filmography.html?p_id=79561 Filmography of Morey Amsterdam] at ''The New York Times'' * [http://radiogoldindex.com/cgi-local/p2.cgi?ProgramName=The+Morey+Amsterdam+Show Catalogue of his shows in the radioGOLDINdex database] * {{Find a Grave|2161}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Amsterdam, Morey}} [[Category:American male comedians]] [[Category:American radio personalities]] [[Category:American male radio actors]] [[Category:American male television actors]] [[Category:American people of Austrian-Jewish descent]] [[Category:Male actors from Chicago]] [[Category:Musicians from Chicago]] [[Category:Jewish American writers]] [[Category:Jewish American male actors]] [[Category:Jewish American musicians]] [[Category:American cellists]] [[Category:1908 births]] [[Category:1996 deaths]] [[Category:Vaudeville performers]] [[Category:Male actors from New York City]] [[Category:Male actors from Los Angeles]] [[Category:Burials at Forest Lawn Memorial Park (Hollywood Hills)]] [[Category:20th-century American male actors]] [[Category:20th-century American musicians]] [[Category:Comedians from California]] [[Category:Comedians from New York City]] [[Category:Comedians from Illinois]] [[Category:Jewish American comedians]] [[Category:20th-century American comedians]]

{{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = Nick Gillard | image = Nick Gillard.jpg | image_size = 200px | caption = | birth_place = [[Brighton]], England, United Kingdom | birth_date =1959 | occupation = Stunt coordinator
Fight choreographer | yearsactive = 1979 – present | spouse = }} '''Nick Gillard''' is an English [[stunt man]] and [[stunt coordinator|coordinator]]. He is best known as the technical [[lightsaber]] choreographer and stunt coordinator for the [[Star Wars#Prequel trilogy|''Star Wars'' prequels]]. ==Biography== Gillard was born in [[Brighton, England]] At the age of twelve, Gillard ran away from [[military school]] to join the circus where he performed as bareback horse rider. Over the next few years Gillard worked with several circus's including [[Circus Althoff]] in Germany and [[Los Muchachos Circus]] in Spain. Gillard was invited to do [[stunts]] on ''[[The Thief of Baghdad (1978 film)|The Thief of Baghdad]]''. He enjoyed it, and later left the circus to perform stunt work in films, including the [[Star Wars (film)|original ''Star Wars'']].{{cite web |url=http://www.starwars.com/bio/nickgillard.html |title=Star Wars: Bio – Nick Gillard |publisher=Lucasfilm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20030808175631/http://www.starwars.com/bio/nickgillard.html |archivedate=8 August 2003 |accessdate=2 December 2013 }}{{cite web |url= http://www.denofgeek.com/movies/star-wars/18028/star-wars-den-of-geek-goes-jedi-training-with-nick-gillard |title=Star Wars: Den of Geek goes Jedi training with Nick Gillard |work=Den of Geek |date=12 September 2011 |accessdate=2 December 2013}} As a stunt man, Gillard held the world record for longest fire stunt, with a fire burn without air for over two minutes on ''[[Alien 3]]''.[https://books.google.com/books?id=WtG8KF73Rc4C&q=%22nick+gillard%22+guinness&dq=%22nick+gillard%22+guinness&hl=pt-PT&sa=X&ei=gqcXUdr8BMuM0QH-5oGYCA&ved=0CDUQ6AEwAA Guinness Book of Records] He also performed a 200-foot power boat jump over two bridges in the film ''[[Amsterdamned]]'', and was set on fire over 100 times. He had a minor role in ''[[Star Wars: Episode III – Revenge of the Sith]]'' as [[Jedi Master]] Cin Drallig ("Nic Gillard" spelled backwards) and was [[Mark Hamill]]'s first choice as his stunt double for ''[[Return of the Jedi]]''. Among his movie credits are ''[[Sleepy Hollow (film)|Sleepy Hollow]]'', ''[[Robin Hood: Prince of Thieves]]'', ''[[Raiders of the Lost Ark]]'' and ''[[Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade]]''. ==As stunt coordinator, arranger or performer== ===Film=== {{Div col|colwidth=30em}} * 1977 ''[[The Spy Who Loved Me (film)|The Spy Who Loved Me]]'' * 1981 ''[[For Your Eyes Only (film)|For Your Eyes Only]]'' * 1983 ''[[Krull (film)|Krull]]'' * 1984 ''[[Scream for Help]]'' * 1985 ''[[Restless Natives]]'' * 1985 ''[[The Bride (1985 film)|The Bride]]'' * 1985 ''[[Legend (1985 film)|Legend]]'' * 1985 ''[[Murder Elite]]'' * 1985 ''[[Claudia (1985 film)|Claudia]]'' * 1985 ''[[Christmas Present (1985 film)|Christmas Present]]'' * 1986 ''[[Labyrinth (film)|Labyrinth]]'' * 1986 ''[[Aliens (film)|Aliens]]'' * 1987 ''[[The Living Daylights]]'' * 1987 ''[[Empire of the Sun (film)|Empire of the Sun]]'' * 1988 ''[[Amsterdamned]]'' * 1988 ''[[Willow (film)|Willow]]'' * 1988 ''[[Dream Demon]]'' * 1988 ''[[The Beast (1988 film)|The Beast of War]]'' * 1989 ''[[Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade]]'' * 1989 ''[[Henry V (1989 film)|Henry V]]'' * 1990 ''[[1871 (film)|1871]]'' * 1990 ''[[Frankenstein Unbound]]'' * 1990 ''[[Bullseye! (Sri Lanka) | adsl chan 1 = Channel 60 | adsl serv 2 =[[Dhiraagu TV]]
(Maldives) | adsl chan 2 =Channel 168 }} '''Nickelodeon India''' is an Indian children's pay television network based in [[Mumbai]]. It is the Indian equivalent to the [[Nickelodeon|original American network]] and is owned by [[Viacom 18]], a joint venture between [[Viacom]] and [[TV18]]. Nick India is available in four languages: [[Hindi]], [[Tamil language|Tamil]], [[Telugu language|Telugu]] and [[Kannada language|Kannada]]. ==History== Nickelodeon India was launched on 16 October 1999 and was initially picked up by [[Zee TV]].{{cite web|url=http://www.indiantelevision.com/news_analysis/newsletter/111099/zee111099.htm|title=ZEE TV TO LAUNCH NICKELODEON|date=October 11, 1999|accessdate=June 21, 2017}} [[Zee TV]] launched a Nickelodeon-branded programming block as part of a distribution deal between Viacom International and [[Zee Entertainment Enterprises]]. It was replaced by the [[Cartoon Network India|Cartoon Network]] block in 2002.{{cite web|url=http://www.indiantelevision.com/y2k2/aug/aug87.htm|title=Cartoon Network block replaces Nick on Zee TV|date=August 14, 2002|accessdate=September 19, 2017}} In 2004 Viacom revamped Nickelodeon in India to increase its viewership, including branding it as Nick, local productions and starting Hindi feed.{{Cite web|url=http://www.animationxpress.com/index.php/interviews/nickelodeon-india-business-and-operations-head-pradeep-hejmadi|title=Nickelodeon India business and operations head Pradeep Hejmadi - AnimationXpressAnimationXpress|website=www.animationxpress.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-07-20}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.indiantelevision.com/headlines/y2k4/may/may182.htm|title=Nick to get 'MTV India treatment' for makeover|date=2004-05-22|work=Indian Television Dot Com|access-date=2018-07-20|language=en}} Viacom signed a programming deal with [[Sun Network]] in 2007 according to which Nickelodeon shows will air on [[Chutti TV]] dubbed in Tamil and Telugu. This deal was later cancelled when Nickelodeon decided to add Tamil and Telugu language tracks to their own channel.{{cite web|url=http://www.indiantelevision.com/headlines/y2k9/dec/dec197.php|title=Sun's Chutti TV targets 25% ad growth in 2010|date=19 December 2009|accessdate=January 9, 2018}} On June 25, 2010 Nick India rebranded using the current logo. It was the last major market to undergo this makeover.{{Cite news|url=https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/industry/media/entertainment/media/nick-india-undergoes-makeover-to-don-new-logo-from-june-25/articleshow/6087665.cms|title=Nick India undergoes makeover, to don new logo from June 25|date=2010-06-24|work=The Economic Times|access-date=2018-03-03}} In 2011, Viacom 18 launched a new channel called [[Nickelodeon Sonic|Sonic]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.campaignindia.in/article/viacom18-to-launch-new-channel-sonic-for-new-young-adults/415351|title=Viacom18 to launch new channel Sonic for "new young adults"|work=Campaign India|access-date=2017-11-01}} Initially the channel was focused on action and adventure, before switching their focus to comedy in 2016.{{Cite web|url=http://www.animationxpress.com/index.php/latest-news/nick-rebrands-their-kids-channel-sonic-with-refreshing-new-logo-and-their-successful-show-shiva|title=Nick rebrands their kids channel Sonic with refreshing new logo and their successful show 'Shiva' - AnimationXpressAnimationXpress|website=www.animationxpress.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-11-01}} [[Viacom 18 Motion Pictures]] distributed ''Keymon & Nani in Space Adventure'', a film based on the Nickelodeon India series ''Keymon Ache'' in 2012. Another theatrical film, ''[[Motu Patlu: King Of Kings]]'' from the ''[[Motu Patlu]]'' franchise was released in Hindi and Tamil on 14 October 2016.{{cite web|url= https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/tv/trade-news/hindi/Viacom18-to-bring-Motu-Patlu-King-of-Kings-animation-film/articleshow/54196439.cms|title=Viacom18 to bring 'Motu Patlu King of Kings' animation film|accessdate=September 8, 2016}} [[Nick Jr India|Nick Jr. India]] was launched in late 2012 after being spun off from the main channel.{{Cite web|url=http://www.televisionpost.com/television/viacom18-launches-nick-jr-to-enter-preschool-segment-in-india/|title=Viacom18 launches Nick Jr. to enter preschool segment in India {{!}} TelevisionPost.com|website=www.televisionpost.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-11-01}} [[TeenNick India|TeenNick]] aired in the evenings before 1 February 2017, when it was discontinued. In 2013 the first ever [[Nickelodeon Kids' Choice Awards India|Kids Choice Awards]] was hosted in India.{{Cite news|url=http://www.indiantelevision.com/release/y2k13/oct/octrel54.php|title=Nickelodeon Kids Choice Awards now in India|date=2013-10-10|work=Indian Television Dot Com|access-date=2017-11-01}} On 5 December 2015, [[Viacom 18]] launched Nickelodeon HD+, the first children's channel in high definition in India.{{Cite web|url=http://www.televisionpost.com/television/viacom18-to-launch-hd-kids-channel-nick-hd-unveils-local-ip-shiva-for-nick/|title=Viacom18 to launch HD kids channel Nick HD+, unveils local IP 'Shiva' for Nick {{!}} TelevisionPost.com|website=www.televisionpost.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-11-01|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170708010213/http://www.televisionpost.com/television/viacom18-to-launch-hd-kids-channel-nick-hd-unveils-local-ip-shiva-for-nick/|archivedate=8 July 2017|df=dmy-all}} It originates a different schedule than the main network, including previously unaired international programming such as ''[[The Legend of Korra]]''. In 2016 Viacom 18 launched a Nick programming block named "Nick Hour" on their [[free-to-air]] channel [[Rishtey (TV channel)|Rishtey]].{{cite web|url=https://ddfreedish.site/tag/nick-hour-rishtey-channel/|title="Nick Hour" on Rishtey|date=March 30, 2016|accessdate=December 13, 2017}} The programming consists of shows like ''[[Motu Patlu]]'', ''[[Pakdam Pakdai]]'', [[The Jungle Book (TV series)|''The Jungle Book'']], ''[[Go, Diego, Go!]]'', ''Keymon Ache'' and ''[[Chhoti Anandi]]'' ([[Colors TV|Colors]] series). Nick India launched [[Kannada]] feed on 1 September 2018. ==Programming== {{Main|List of programmes broadcast by Nickelodeon (India)}} In the channel's first years of broadcasting it aired mostly original programmes from the US, like ''[[Rugrats]]'', ''[[Aaahh! Real Monsters]]'', ''[[As Told by Ginger]]'', ''[[Rocket Power]]'', ''[[The Wild Thornberrys]]'' and other animated shows such as ''[[The Adventures of Jimmy Neutron: Boy Genius]]'', ''[[Rocko's Modern Life]]'', ''[[The Angry Beavers]]'', ''[[CatDog]]'', ''[[Hey Arnold!]]'', ''[[The Fairly OddParents]]'' and ''[[Danny Phantom]]''. The network also aired live action shows, such as ''[[Kenan & Kel]]'', ''[[Drake & Josh]]'', ''[[Clarissa Explains It All]]'', ''[[Legends of the Hidden Temple]]'', Nick Bites and many more. After the success of international game shows Nick India produced two local game shows, ''Dum Dama Dum''{{Cite news|url=http://www.indiantelevision.com/headlines/y2k4/nov/nov86.htm|title=Nick brings 'Double Dare' Hindi version|date=2004-11-09|work=Indian Television Dot Com|access-date=2017-11-02}} and ''Gilli Gilli Gappa''.{{cite web|url=http://www.indiantelevision.com/headlines/y2k6/mar/mar175.htm|title=Nick launches "Gilli Gilli Gappa" on Holi|date=March 14, 2006|accessdate=November 18, 2017}} They launched [[Krrish (franchise)#J Bole Toh Jadoo .282003.29|''J Bole Toh Jadoo'']], a spin-off series of 2003's ''[[Koi... Mil Gaya]]''. The series premiered on 14 November 2005 on [[Children's Day]]. In 2006 Nick India started acquiring Japanese series such as [[Ninja Hattori-kun|''Ninja Hattori'']], [[Perman (manga)#Anime|''Perman'']] and ''[[Mighty Cat Masked Niyander]]''.{{Cite web|url=http://www.animationxpress.com/index.php/animation/nick-scores-hat-trick-with-new-shows-on-board|title=Nick scores hat trick with new shows on board - AnimationXpressAnimationXpress|website=www.animationxpress.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-01-10}} Nick started airing [[Colors TV|Colors]]'s Mythological show ''[[Jai Shri Krishna]]'' in 2009. The show was re-edited and customised for children.{{cite web|url=http://www.afaqs.com/news/story/23109_Colors-to-share-Jai-Shri-Krishna-with-Nick-but-with-a-different-touch|title=Colors to share Jai Shri Krishna with Nick, but with a different touch|date=January 16, 2009|accessdate=November 27, 2017}} They also acquired ''[[Little Krishna]]'', an animated series produced by BIG Animation India and The Indian Heritage Foundation in May 2009.{{cite news|url= http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/todays-paper/tp-others/tp-variety/animation-series-little-krishna-debut-on-may-11/article1051136.ece|title=Animation series ‘Little Krishna’ debut on May 11|date=May 7, 2009|accessdate=January 10, 2018}} Nickelodeon India from 2011 started producing local animated programming and launched ''[[Keymon Ache]]'' and a theatrical movie based on the series.{{cite web|url=http://www.indiantelevision.com/headlines/y2k12/nov/nov62.php|title=Nick's Keymon Ache to make its theatrical debut on 9 November|date=November 6, 2012|accessdate=January 4, 2017}} The local strategy became successful with ''[[Motu Patlu]]'' in 2012 and they later launched more local animated series like ''[[Pakdam Pakdai]]'' in 2013, ''[[Shiva (animated TV series)|Shiva]]'' in 2015, ''[[Gattu Battu]]'' in 2017 and ''[[Rudra: Boom Chik Chik Boom|Rudra]]'' in 2018. Nickelodeon India for a long time has been giving less importance on American original series. Many of the [[Nickelodeon Animation Studio#Nickelodeon (main shows)|animated shows]] have been neglected by the channel and even internationally popular shows like ''[[The Fairly OddParents]]'' haven't had a proper run on the channel. The probable cause of this is due to the channel's low ratings and failure to gain relevance with the children in its first years of broadcasting.{{Cite news|url=http://www.indiantelevision.com/interviews/y2k7/executive/Nina_Jaipuria.htm|title='The focus for Nick in 2007 is to drive reach' : Nina Elavia Jaipuria - Nick India vice president & general manager|date=2007-02-12|work=Indian Television Dot Com|access-date=2018-07-20|language=en}} [[Nick Jr. (India)|Nick Jr.]] also wasn't in a good condition until 2012 when the dedicated channel launched and the new [[Nickelodeon Animation Studio#Noggin/Nick Jr. Network (preschool shows)|shows from Nick Jr.]] started airing. Nick India did not even broadcast live action series such as [[ICarly|''iCarly'']] until several years later with the launch of the now-discontinued [[TeenNick (India)|TeenNick]] block on [[Nick Jr. (India)|Nick Jr. India]]. Nina Elavia Jaipuria, the head of Nickelodeon India says live action shows do not connect with the viewers as much as animated shows do, even with dubbing.{{Cite web|url=http://bestmediainfo.com/2018/06/ad-rate-correction-alone-will-not-correct-the-index-says-nick-s-nina-elavia-jaipuria/|title=Ad rate correction alone will not correct the index, says Nick’s Nina Elavia Jaipuria|website=www.bestmediaifo.com|access-date=2018-07-20}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.televisionpost.com/our-gameplan-is-to-maximise-market-and-revenue-share/|title=‘Our gameplan is to maximise market and revenue share’ – TelevisionPost: Latest News, India’s Television, Cable, DTH, TRAI|website=www.televisionpost.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-07-20}} In August 2018, Nick HD+ changed its schedule with a larger focus on original Nickelodeon shows from the US, while the standard-definition Nick channel continues to only show locally made series for the masses. ==See also== *[[Indian_animation_industry#Animated_TV_series_produced_in_India|List of Indian animated TV series]] *[[Nickelodeon (Pakistan)]] *[[List of programmes broadcast by Cartoon Network (India)]] *[[List of programs broadcast by Hungama TV|List of programmes broadcast by Hungama TV]] *[[List of programmes broadcast by Pogo]] *[[List of programs broadcast by Disney Channel (India)|List of programmes broadcast by Disney Channel (India)]] *[[Discovery Kids (India)]] *[[Disney XD (India)]] *[[Sony Yay]] ==External links== *{{Official website|https://www.nickindia.com/}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{Nickelodeon}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Nickelodeon India}} [[Category:Nickelodeon|India]] [[Category:Children's television channels in India]] [[Category:Indian animation]] [[Category:Television channels and stations established in 1999]] [[Category:English-language television stations in India]] [[Category:Television stations in Mumbai]] [[Category:1999 establishments in India]] [[Category:Viacom 18]]

Andrew Appelle | editor = Robert Hyland
Curt Lobb | runtime = 22 minutes | company =Zapruder Films |network = {{Plainlist| *[[Viceland]] *[[City (TV network)|City]] }} | picture_format =[[1080i]] ([[16:9]] [[HDTV]]) | first_aired = February 2, 2017 | last_aired = present | website = https://video.vice.com/en_ca/show/nirvanna-the-band-the-show }} '''''Nirvanna the Band the Show''''' is a [[Canada|Canadian]] mockumentary television series based on the [[web series]] of the same name, created by and starring [[Matt Johnson (director)|Matt Johnson]] and Jay McCarrol. It premiered on February 2, 2017 on [[Viceland]].{{cite web|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/arts/awards-and-festivals/tiff/matt-johnson-the-enemy-inside-tiffs-gates/article31793991/ |title='Can-con bad boy' Matt Johnson: Meet the enemy inside TIFF’s gates |publisher=''[[The Globe and Mail]]'' |date=September 9, 2016 |accessdate=September 12, 2016}} The show has been renewed for a third season and there are plans for a fourth. ==Premise== The show stars the duo as "Nirvanna the Band," two hapless lifelong best friends and roommates, who engage in a series of complex [[publicity stunt]]s around their home city of [[Toronto]] in the hopes of landing a gig at [[The Rivoli]], despite the fact that they have never actually written or recorded a single song, nor taken any other steps to get their band ready.{{cite web|url=https://nowtoronto.com/movies/television/nirvanna-the-band-the-show-is-back-viceland-september-2016/ |title=Nirvanna the Band the Show is back – but this time it's bigger and on proper TV |publisher=''[[Now (newspaper)|Now Magazine]]'' |date=June 6, 2016 |accessdate=September 12, 2016}} ==Production== The show is a combination of scripted scenes, candid camera footage of people unaware the show is being filmed, and improvisation. Often times the show is influenced by events that happen in reality. For example, in the fifth episode, "The Big Time", creators Johnson and McCarrol used the premiere of Johnson's real life movie ''[[Operation Avalanche (film)|Operation Avalanche]]'' at the [[2016 Sundance Film Festival]] to film an episode around the concept of the character Matt sneaking a fictional movie of the same name into the festival. In the same episode, a woman unaware of the show being filmed intrudes on a scripted conversation between Johnson and [[Kevin Smith]] (appearing as himself), offering Johnson alcohol, which inspired Johnson and McCarrol to include the concept of the character of Matt discovering a love of alcohol in the episode. The show frequently blends the line between fiction and reality in ways like these, with actors breaking character and characters breaking the [[fourth wall]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DjWd0a7wS4E|title=Thoughts on Nirvanna the Band the Show|last=|first=|date=|website=Youtube|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} Originally created as web series between 2007 and 2009, it was later expanded into a full television series which premiered on [[Viceland]] on February 2, 2017.{{cite web|url=http://exclaim.ca/film/article/nirvanna_the_band_the_show-created_by_matt_johnson_and_jay_mccarrol |title=nirvanna the band the show |publisher=''[[Exclaim!]]'' |date=September 11, 2016 |accessdate=September 12, 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://cartt.ca/article/viceland%E2%80%99s-original-comedy-%E2%80%98nirvanna-band-show%E2%80%99-arrives-february-2 |title=Viceland’s original comedy ‘Nirvanna the Band the Show’ arrives February 2 |publisher=''Cartt.ca'' |date=January 27, 2017 |accessdate=January 29, 2017}} Three episodes were also screened at the [[2016 Toronto International Film Festival]] as part of its ''Primetime'' program of television projects.{{cite web|url=https://nowtoronto.com/movies/television/nirvanna-the-band-to-premiere-at-tiff-2016/ |title=Nirvanna the Band the Show to premiere at TIFF |publisher=''[[Now (newspaper)|Now Magazine]]'' |date=August 3, 2016 |accessdate=September 12, 2016}} The series was originally announced in 2016 as slated to air on [[City (TV network)|City]], but was later shifted to Viceland with City airing only the first episode as a preview special. The second season has not been picked up for broadcast outside of Canada, however is available for streaming in Australia via [[SBS_(Australian_TV_channel)#SBS_On_Demand|SBS On Demand]] and in Britain via [[Channel 4]] On Demand. The characters, Matt and Jay, are based on characters McCarrol and Johnson started developing in high school in Mississauga.{{cite web|url=https://nowtoronto.com/movies/nirvanna-the-band-the-show-viceland-matt-johnson-jay-mccarrol/ |title=Nirvanna the Band the Show puts Toronto front and centre in hilarious new show for VICELAND Jay gets lost at Toronto's 4/20 festival. ----'''Opening Title:''' [[The Walking Dead (TV series)|The Walking Dead]] | LineColor = 3B3B48 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 13 | EpisodeNumber2 = 6 | Title = The Banned | DirectedBy = Matt Johnson | WrittenBy = Andrew Appelle, Robert Hyland, Curt Lobb, Jay McCarrol, Matthew Miller, Jared Raab | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2017|11|24}} | Viewers = {{TableTBA|N/A}} | ShortSummary = Matt and Jay convince a computer store employee to try to hack into the Rivoli's computer. ----'''Opening Title:''' [[Hackers (film)|Hackers]] | LineColor = 3B3B48 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 14 | EpisodeNumber2 = 1 | Title = The Burger | DirectedBy = Matt Johnson | WrittenBy = Andrew Appelle, Robert Hyland, Curt Lobb, Jay McCarrol, Matthew Miller, Jared Raab | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2017|12|08}} | Viewers = {{TableTBA|N/A}} | ShortSummary = Matt and Jay try to stick to one plan for the entire season. ----'''Opening Title:''' [[Wahlburgers]] | LineColor = 3B3B48 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 16 | EpisodeNumber2 = 8 | Title = The Banned List 2 | AltTitle = The Betrayal | DirectedBy = Matt Johnson | WrittenBy = Andrew Appelle, Robert Hyland, Curt Lobb, Jay McCarrol, Matthew Miller, Jared Raab | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2018|01|12}}
February 9, 2018 | Viewers = {{TableTBA|N/A}} | ShortSummary = After Matt and Jay's previous plan fails, they find themselves stuck on the Rivoli's roof. | LineColor = 3B3B48 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 15 | EpisodeNumber2 = 7 | Title = The Band List | DirectedBy = Matt Johnson | WrittenBy = Andrew Appelle, Robert Hyland, Curt Lobb, Jay McCarrol, Matthew Miller, Jared Raab | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2018|02|09}} | Viewers = {{TableTBA|N/A}} | ShortSummary = Matt and Jay sneak into Toronto's underground tunnels to get under the Rivoli. ----'''Opening Title:''' Indiana Jones | LineColor = 3B3B48 }} }} == Critical reception == The show has received mostly positive reviews. Jake Howell of [[The Globe and Mail]] praised the show, commenting "Bickering like a married couple, Matt and Jay's constant back-and-forth enabling, backstabbing and belittling of each other has thus far made for great television."{{Cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/arts/television/why-arent-people-watching-nirvanna-the-band-the-show/article36786267/|title=Why aren’t people watching Nirvanna the Band the Show?|access-date=2017-12-15}} Calum Marsh of [[National Post]] gave the series a positive review, stating "The intricate arrangement of jokes, careful plotting of action and meticulous orchestration of references demand considerably more from an audience than one tends to expect of a mainstream sitcom." While Kate Robertson of NOW Toronto was critical of the show's racist jokes saying "The pop culture references are always 90s, and the show aims to preserve a certain part of Toronto that many of us associate with those years. There’s also an uneasy, dated quality to it. Things have changed: ironic racist jokes of the past were never funny after all. They were just excuses to be shocking and racist. Maybe gags like this are an effort to highlight the persistent prejudices from the beginning of political correctness in the 90s, but it’s still a show programmed for a 2017 audience."{{Cite news|url=https://nowtoronto.com/movies/reviews/nirvanna-the-band-the-show-season-two/|title=TV review: Nirvanna The Band The Show's nostalgia schtick is starting to feel dated}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== *[http://www.nirvannathebandtheshow.com Official site] *[https://video.vice.com/en_ca/show/nirvanna-the-band-the-show Official Viceland site] *{{IMDb title|5978570}} {{VICE Media}} [[Category:2010s Canadian satirical television series]] [[Category:2017 Canadian television series debuts]] [[Category:Canadian web series]] [[Category:Canadian mockumentary television series]] [[Category:Comedy web series]] [[Category:Viceland television series]] [[Category:Citytv shows]]

revision.comment: removed [[Category:Fictional nurses]]; added [[Category:Works about nursing]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox film | name = Private Duty Nurses | image = Private Duty Nurses.jpg | caption = | director = [[George Armitage]] | producer = George Armitage | writer = George Armitage | starring = | music = | cinematography = | editing = Alan Collins | distributor = [[New World Pictures]] | released = {{Film date|1971}} | runtime = | country = United States | language = English | budget = | gross = }} '''''Private Duty Nurses''''' is a 1971 film written and directed by [[George Armitage]]. It is a sequel to ''[[The Student Nurses]]'' (1970) for [[New World Pictures]]. [[Roger Corman]] says they got the idea for the title after being sent a letter of complaint about the first film from the Private Duty Nurses Association.{{cite book|first=Christopher T|last= Koetting|title=Mind Warp!: The Fantastic True Story of Roger Corman's New World Pictures|publisher=Hemlock Books|year= 2009 |page=30}} The film was followed by ''[[Night Call Nurses]]'' (1972). ==Cast== *[[Katherine Cannon]] as Spring *Joyce Williams as Lola *Pegi Boucher as Lynn *Joseph Kaufmann as Dr. Selden *Dennis Redfield as Domino *[[Robert F. Simon]] as Dr. Sutton *Morris Buchanan as Kirby *[[Herbert Jefferson, Jr.]] as Dr. Elton *[[Paul Hampton]] as Dewey *[[Paul Gleason]] as Dr. McClintock ==Production== George Armitage had made a few films for Roger Corman, acting in ''[[Von Richtofen and Brown]]'' and writing and acting in ''[[Gas-s-s-s]]''. He wanted to direct. Armitage:
[[Peter Bogdanovich]] and Francis [Ford Coppola] had left working with Roger, so there was an opening there for directors, I asked him if I could direct, and he said sure. He said: “Would you like to do a nurse movie or a stewardess move?” I said I’d like to do a stewardess movie, and he said: “Okay, well then you can do the nurse movie.” Okay! Anyways, I got into it, and I wrote the script, and I got Everett Chambers, from ''[[Peyton Place (TV series)|Peyton Place]]'', a crew of some TV guys that I’d worked with, and some young commercial crew. This fellow called [[Fouad Said]] had invented this thing called Cinemobile... and I used it to film on location. I did everything on location... I shot the whole movie in the South Bay, Manhattan Beach—it’s exactly the same place and time period that [[Paul Thomas Anderson]] used in ''[[Inherent Vice]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.filmcomment.com/blog/interview-george-armitage/|first= Nick |last=Pinkerton|title=Interview with George Armitage|website=Film Comment|date=28 April 2015|access-date=23 August 2016}}
Armitage was familiar with the Manhattan beach area having surfed there when he was younger.{{cite web|url=http://www.money-into-light.com/search/label/Interview%3A%20GEORGE%20ARMITAGE%20%28PART%201%20OF%203%29|website=Money Into Light|title=Interview with George Armitage - Part One}} Armitage said the film had to feature sex but he put in a let-down sex scene at the beginning.
I was talking to the girls and they said: “Hey, why don’t you do a guy who’s just a lousy lay. Sometimes you run into that.” And I thought that’d be perfect for the South Bay, because it was a pretty crazy culture going on down there at the time, so that’s what we did.
Armitage heard about the band Sky, went to see them perform at a high school, and cast them in the film. Armitage says Corman left him alone for most of the film.
He wanted us to do whatever we felt, what we were thinking of poetically, socially, culturally at the time. So I tried to look at it from a woman’s point-of-view, adding my own feelings about what was going on. Corman and I got along very well. I didn’t like the way Hollywood treated him—he was kind of an underdog and I loved the fact that he would just say, “Here, go make the movie.” He never came to the set, he totally allowed us to do what we were doing... And ''Private Duty Nurses'' was done in 15 days.
==See also== * [[List of American films of 1971]] * [[List of American films of 1970]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb title|0067618}} {{Nurses cycle}} {{George Armitage}} [[Category:Exploitation films]] [[Category:1970 films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:New World Pictures films]] [[Category:Works about nursing]] [[Category:Medical-themed films]] [[Category:Sequel films]]

{{Infobox pro wrestling championship |championshipname=ROH World Television Championship |image=ROH TV Title.jpg |alt= |image_size= |caption= |currentholder=[[Jeff Cobb]] |won=September 29, 2018 |aired= |promotion=[[Ring of Honor]] (ROH) |created=January 20, 2010 |mostreigns=[[Jay Lethal]], [[Kenny King (wrestler)|Kenny King]], [[Roderick Strong]], [[Silas Young]] ([[#List of combined reigns|2 reigns]]) |firstchamp=[[Eddie Edwards (wrestler)|Eddie Edwards]] |longestreign=[[Jay Lethal]] ({{age in days nts|month1=4|day1=4|year1=2014|month2=10|day2=23|year2=2015}} days) |shortestreign=[[Will Ospreay]] ({{age in days nts|month1=11|day1=18|year1=2016|month2=11|day2=20|year2=2016}} days) |oldest=[[Christopher Daniels]], 41 years |youngest=[[Adam Cole]], 22 years |heaviest=[[Jeff Cobb]] (263 lb.) |lightest=[[Will Ospreay]] (174 lb.) |pastnames= |titleretired= |pastlookimages= }} The '''ROH World Television Championship''' is a [[professional wrestling]] [[Championship (professional wrestling)#Gimmick/style championships|world television championship]] in the [[Ring of Honor]] (ROH) [[professional wrestling promotion|promotion]]. With the introduction of the ROH World Television Championship, the [[Championship (professional wrestling)#Gimmick/style championships|television type championship]] returned to national exposure. There has been a total of seventeen reigns shared between fourteen champions. The first champion was crowned on March 5, 2010, when [[Eddie Edwards (wrestler)|Eddie Edwards]] defeated [[Davey Richards]] in the finals of a tournament. The current champion is [[Jeff Cobb]], who is in his first reign.{{cite web|url=https://prowrestling.net/site/2018/06/17/6-16-roh-in-dallas-results-new-roh-tv-champion-crowned-the-briscoes-vs-killer-elite-squad-for-the-roh-tag-titles-cody-vs-shane-taylor-the-young-bucks-vs-the-boys-jay-lethal-vs-marty-scurll-vs/|title=6/16 ROH in Dallas results: New ROH TV Champion crowned, The Briscoes vs. Killer Elite Squad for the ROH Tag Titles, Cody vs. Shane Taylor, The Young Bucks vs. The Boys, Jay Lethal vs. Marty Scurll vs. Flip Gordon |last=Powell|first=Jason|date=2018-06-17|work=[[Ring of Honor]]| Jay Lethal's second reign is the longest in the title's history. During that reign, Lethal also won the [[ROH World Championship]] in a Title vs. Title match at [[Best in the World 2015]]. ==History== The creation of the ROH World Television Championship was announced via ROH's official website on January 20, 2010. An [[Single-elimination tournament|eight-man single elimination tournament]] was then planned to determine the inaugural champion. The tournament was to start on February 4 and conclude on February 6, 2010 at [[The Arena (Philadelphia)|The Arena]] in [[Philadelphia|Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]] at the [[Broadcast delay|tapings]] of ROH's television program ''[[Ring of Honor Wrestling]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.wrestleview.com/viewnews.php?id=1264017860|title=Ring of Honor to add new TV title|last=Gerweck|first=Steve|date=2010-01-20|work=[[Ring of Honor]]|publisher=WrestleView.com|accessdate=2011-06-28}} Regarding the new championship addition, ROH President Cary Silkin said, "We’ve been talking about adding a secondary championship for some time. Not only will this give the athletes of Ring of Honor another tremendous goal to work towards, it will also give our great partner, HDNet, a championship that is sure to be defended on the television program. We’re happy to publicly give thanks to HDNet for giving us the chance to add this title to the television show...". It is ROH's second secondary singles championship in their history. The [[ROH Pure Championship]] was used from February 14, 2004 to August 12, 2006, prior its [[Championship unification#Professional wrestling|unification]] with the [[ROH World Championship]].{{cite web|url=http://www.rohwrestling.com/rohpuretitle.php|title=ROH Pure Championship reign history|publisher=ROH Wrestling.com|accessdate=2010-04-07|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100404064124/http://www.rohwrestling.com/rohpuretitle.php |archivedate=2010-04-04}} After the championship announcement, wrestling columnist James Caldwell gave his comments: "I like the idea. It gives mid-card wrestlers on ROH's roster something to fight for in the context of trying to win a wrestling match to "move up the company ladder." Caldwell further remarked that "ROH bringing back the TV Title to national TV is consistent with ROH's current marketing under Jim Cornette to "re-capture an old-school flavor" to their product." After the ''Ring of Honor Wrestling'' show was cancelled in March 2011, the title became inactive. Although Daniels stopped defending it, he still carried the belt with him as part of his villainous character. With the sale of ROH to the [[Sinclair Broadcast Group]] and a new television show scheduled to air in September, ROH reinstated the title for June's Best in The World event.{{cite web|title=Who Will Represent ROH On Broadcast TV?|url=http://www.rohwrestling.com/news/who-will-represent-roh-on-broadcast-tv/|publisher=[[Ring of Honor]]|accessdate=2011-06-08}}{{cite web|last=Caldwell|first=James|title=ROH TV Title match announced for "Best in the World" Internet PPV this month|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/ROH_News_29/article_50599.shtml|publisher=PWTorch|accessdate=2011-06-08|date=2011-06-07}} ===Tournament=== The tournament was scheduled to span over a two-day weekend, starting on February 5 and ending on February 6 at events recorded for later broadcast on ''Ring of Honor Wrestling''. However, due to [[February 5–6, 2010 North American blizzard#Mid-Atlantic|severe weather conditions]] in the Philadelphia area, the second day of taping was canceled.{{cite web|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/ROH_News_29/article_38804.shtml|title=Ring of Honor cancels tonight's ROH TV taping |last=Caldwell|first=James|date=2010-02-06|publisher=PWTorch|accessdate=2010-02-06}} It was not until almost a month later, on March 5, that ROH held the second recorded event, which closed out the tournament.{{cite web|url=http://www.f4wonline.com/content/view/12560/105/|title=ROH TV tapings from Friday & Saturday night|last=Sosnowski|first=Paul|date=2010-03-05|publisher=Wrestling Observer/Figure Four Online|accessdate=2010-04-07}} The first four seeds of eight in the tournament were announced on January 22, 2010: [[Rhett Titus]] (8), [[El Generico]] (7), [[Eddie Edwards (wrestler)|Eddie Edwards]] (6), and [[Delirious (wrestler)|Delirious]] (5).{{cite web|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/ROH_News_29/article_38349.shtml|title=ROH News: First four wrestlers announced for TV Title tournament|last=Caldwell|first=James|date=2010-01-22|work=PWTorch.com|publisher=TDH Communications Inc.|accessdate=2010-01-23}} The other four seeds were announced on January 26, 2010: [[Kevin Owens|Kevin Steen]] (1), [[Kenny King (wrestler)|Kenny King]] (2), [[Colt Cabana]] (3), and [[Davey Richards]] (4).{{cite web|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/ROH_News_29/article_38445.shtml|title=ROH News: Top four seeds announced for TV Title tournament, Complete Bracket|last=Caldwell|first=James|date=2010-01-26|work=PWTorch.com|publisher=TDH Communications Inc.|accessdate=2010-01-27}} The first round was determined at the first event on February 5, with Steen, King, Richards, and Edwards all advancing to round two.{{cite web|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/ROH_News_29/article_38797.shtml|title=ROH News: Spoilers - First Round TV Title tournament results, Final rounds set for Saturday TV taping|last=Caldwell|first=James|date=2010-02-05|work=PWTorch.com|publisher=TDH Communications Inc.|accessdate=2010-02-06}} On March 5, Edwards and Richards both advanced to the finals, where Edwards defeat Richards to be crowned the first ROH World Television Champion.{{cite web|url=http://www.f4wonline.com/content/view/12542/105/|title=First ROH TV champion|publisher=Wrestling Observer/Figure Four Online|accessdate=2010-04-07}} The matches were scheduled to span over six episodes of ''Ring of Honor Wrestling''.{{cite web|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/ROH_News_29/article_38277.shtml|title=ROH News: Ring of Honor to debut TV Title, tournament scheduled (w/Video)|last=Caldwell|first=James|date=2010-01-20|work=PWTorch.com|publisher=TDH Communications Inc.|accessdate=2010-01-22}} The first match from round one that aired pitted Steen against Titus, which Steen won, on the March 8 episode.{{cite web|url=http://www.f4wonline.com/content/view/12581/105/|title=ROH TV report (March 8)|last=Collins|first=Paul|date=2010-03-08|publisher=Wrestling Observer/Figure Four Online|accessdate=2010-04-07}} On the same episode, King versus El Generico was featured, with King advancing. Cabana versus Edwards was the third match from round one to air, when it was broadcast on the March 15 episode.{{cite web|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/TV_Reports_9/article_39883.shtml|title=Derosenroll's ROH TV report 3/15: TV Title tournament continues with Davey Richards vs. Delirious, Cabana vs. Edwards|last=Derosenroll|first=Mike|date=2010-03-16|work=PWTorch.com|publisher=TDH Communications Inc.|accessdate=2010-04-07}} Richards defeated Delirious in the final match from round one, which aired later in the same episode. The first match from round two, Steen versus Edwards, was featured on the April 12 episode, in which Edwards advanced to the finals.{{cite web|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/ringofhonor/article_40633.shtml|title=Derosenroll's ROH TV report 4/12: ROH TV Title tournament continues - Edwards vs. Steen, Generico vs. Corino|last=Derosenroll|first=Mike|date=2010-04-14|work=PWTorch.com|publisher=TDH Communications Inc.|accessdate=2010-04-14}} On the April 19 episode, Richards defeated King to advance to the finals.{{cite web|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/ringofhonor/article_40811.shtml|title=Derosenroll's ROH TV report 4/19: ROH TV Title tournament continues - Davey Richards vs. Kenny King, Finals set for next week|last=Derosenroll|first=Mike|date=2010-04-21|work=PWTorch.com|publisher=TDH Communications Inc.|accessdate=2010-04-22}} On the April 26 episode, Edwards defeated Richards in the finals of the tournament to become the first ROH World Television Champion.{{cite web|url=http://wrestleview.com/viewnews.php?id=1272780140|title=ROH HDNet Recap- 4/26/10|last=Martin|first=Adam|date=2010-05-02|work=WrestleView.com|accessdate=2010-05-09|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100505194733/http://www.wrestleview.com/viewnews.php?id=1272780140|archivedate=2010-05-05|df=}} ;Tournament Bracket {{8TeamBracket |RD1=Round One
(''[[Ring of Honor Wrestling]]'') |RD2=Round Two
(''[[Ring of Honor Wrestling]]'') |RD3=Finals
(''[[Ring of Honor Wrestling]]'') |group1= |group2= |score-width=35px |team-width=210px |RD1-seed1=1 |RD1-team1='''[[Kevin Owens|Kevin Steen]]''' |RD1-score1=Pin |RD1-seed2=8 |RD1-team2=[[Rhett Titus]] |RD1-score2=The time for this match is unknown. |RD1-seed3=3 |RD1-team3=[[Colt Cabana]] |RD1-score3=10:00 |RD1-seed4=6 |RD1-team4='''[[Eddie Edwards (wrestler)|Eddie Edwards]]''' |RD1-score4=Pin |RD1-seed5=5 |RD1-team5=[[Delirious (wrestler)|Delirious]] |RD1-score5=13:30 |RD1-seed6=4 |RD1-team6='''[[Davey Richards]]''' |RD1-score6=Pin |RD1-seed7=7 |RD1-team7=[[Sami Zayn|El Generico]] |RD1-score7= |RD1-seed8=2 |RD1-team8='''[[Kenny King (wrestler)|Kenny King]]''' |RD1-score8=Pin |RD2-seed1= |RD2-team1=Kevin Steen |RD2-score1= |RD2-seed2= |RD2-team2='''Eddie Edwards''' |RD2-score2=Pin |RD2-seed3= |RD2-team3='''Davey Richards''' |RD2-score3=Pin |RD2-seed4= |RD2-team4=Kenny King |RD2-score4= |RD3-seed1= |RD3-team1='''Eddie Edwards''' |RD3-score1=Sub |RD3-seed2= |RD3-team2=Davey Richards |RD3-score2=20:02 }} ===Belt designs=== The championship belt was introduced on March 5, 2010, when it was given to the newly crowned inaugural champion Eddie Edwards. The physical championship belt was designed All Star Championship Belts d/b/a ASCB, LLC. The title's base is a black leather strap that is covered with four small silver plates. The center of the title has one large silver plate. All plates have an inner blue covering. The two small outer plates have a caricature of the earth and a [[satellite]] in [[orbit]]. The middle plates have figures resembling a [[camera operator|cameraman]] filming a television production. Underneath each figure, lies the ROH logo and the words "Ring of Honor Wrestling". The central plate has the engravings of the ROH logo as well as the statement "World Television Wrestling Champion" hovering above the backdrop of a city, with a television lying on top of a globe with an overhead shot of a wrestling ring between them in front of the [[skyline]].This description is based on the first design of the ROH World Television Championship, as seen in the images throughout the article. The design was changed again in November 2012 to its current design during the reign of Adam Cole, the new design seemed to be based on the [[WCW World Six-Man Tag Team Championship]].[http://www.rohwrestling.com/content/roh-tv-results ROH TV Results] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130124200616/http://www.rohwrestling.com/content/roh-tv-results |date=2013-01-24 }}, rohwrestling.com During [[Jay Lethal]]'s record-setting reign, the belt design was modified to emphasize the "ROH Champion" portion of the title, with Lethal claiming the championship was more prestigious than the [[ROH World Championship]] because he was the champion. On January 1, 2018, ROH announced on their YouTube page that their World Tag, Six Man World Tag Team, and World Television Championships will receive new designs which will debut at the next set of television tapings. ==Champions== Overall, there have been 20 reigns by 16 wrestlers. The inaugural champion was Eddie Edwards, who defeated Davey Richards in the finals of an eight-man tournament on March 5, 2010. The current champion is [[Jeff Cobb]], who is in his first reign as champion. He defeated [[Punishment Martinez]] on September 29, 2018 in [[Las Vegas]], [[Nevada]] during the [[Death Before Dishonor XVI]] TV tapings. {{Professional wrestling title history top|active=yes|defenses=yes}} {{PWtitlereign |number = 1 |champion = [[Eddie Edwards (wrestler)|Eddie Edwards]] |reign = 1 |date = {{dts|2010|03|05}} |days = {{age in days nts|month1=03|day1=05|year1=2010|month2=12|day2=10|year2=2010}} |location = [[Philadelphia|Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]] |event = ''[[Ring of Honor Wrestling]]'' |defenses = 9 |notes = Edwards defeated [[Davey Richards]] in the finals of an eight-man tournament to become the first ROH World Television Champion. The event aired on [[Broadcast delay|tape delay]] on April 26, 2010 |ref = {{cite web|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/ROH_News_29/article_39606.shtml|title=ROH News: Ring of Honor determines first ROH TV champion tonight, A look at the new title belt|last=Caldwell|first=James|date=2010-03-05|publisher=Pro Wrestling Torch|accessdate=2010-03-06}} }}{{PWtitlereign |number = 2 |champion = 1/31/11|last=Rivera|first=Ryan|date=2011-02-01|work=WrestleView.com|accessdate=2011-03-24}} }}{{PWtitlereign |number = 3 |champion = [[Sami Zayn|El Generico]] |reign = 1 |date = {{dts|2011|6|26}} {{italic title}} [[File:Logo Radio Oranje.jpg|thumb|Logo]] [[File:Koningin Wilhelmina Radio Oranje II.jpg|thumb|[[Wilhelmina of the Netherlands|Queen Wilhelmina]] speaking on ''Radio Oranje'']] {{Listen | filename =Media Network - A Voice from Across the Water.ogg | title =A Voice from Across the Water | description =Interview with Loe de Jong about Radio Oranje in 1981 in the programme ''Media Network'' by Jonathan Marks of [[Radio Netherlands Worldwide]]. | pos = }} '''''Radio Oranje''''' ({{IPA-nl|ˈraːdijoː ˌoːˈrɑn.jə|}}; [[Dutch language|Dutch]]: "Radio Orange") was a Dutch-language radio programme on the [[BBC]] European Service managed by the [[Dutch government-in-exile]] and broadcast to the occupied Netherlands during [[World War II]]. It was broadcast from [[London]], and was broadcast for 15 minutes at 9PM each day.
The first broadcast occurred on 28 July 1940, when [[Wilhelmina of the Netherlands|Queen Wilhelmina]] made a speech. In total, Wilhelmina spoke on ''Radio Oranje'' 34 times during the course of the war.
==Presenters== *[[Jan de Hartog]] *[[Loe de Jong]] *[[Herman de Man]] *[[A. den Doolaard]] *[[Jetty Paerl]]
==See also==
*''{{Interlanguage link multi|Radio Vrij Nederland|nl}}'' - (Radio Free Netherlands) Radio Oranje's short-lived predecessor which broadcast from Paris in 1940. *''{{Interlanguage link multi|Radio Herrijzend Nederland|nl}}'' - The service which eventually replaced ''Radio Oranje'', operating from temporary studios in the liberated southern portion of the country in 1944/45. *''[[Radio Belgique]]'' - the Belgian equivalent programme *''[[Radio Londres]]'' - the Free French version
==Bibliography== {{commonscat|Radio Oranje}} * Dra. M. G. Schenk and J. B. Th. Spaan, ''De Koningin Sprak. Proclamaties en radio-toespraken van H.M. Koningin Wilhelmina 1940-1945'', 1945 ({{ISBN|9061353971}}) * H. J. van den Broek, ''Hier Radio Oranje'' * O. Sinke, ''Verzet vanuit de Verte. De Behoedzame Koers van Radio Oranje'', 2009. {{BBC World Service}} [[Category:Netherlands in World War II]] [[Category:Defunct radio stations in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:BBC World Service foreign language]] [[Category:Dutch resistance]] [[Category:Radio stations established in 1940]] [[Category:1940 establishments in the Netherlands]] [[Category:1940 establishments in England]] [[Category:Radio in the Netherlands]] [[Category:1944 disestablishments in the Netherlands]] [[Category:1944 disestablishments in England]] [[Category:Radio during World War II]]

{{Refimprove|date=February 2018}} '''René Clair Award''' ({{lang-fr|Prix René-Clair}}) is an award instituted in 1994 and presented by the ''[[Académie française]]'' for achievements in the field of [[film|cinema]]. The prize was named after the [[France|French]] [[filmmaker]] [[René Clair]].
==Recipients== *1994: [[Alexandre Astruc]] *1995: [[Robert Bresson]] *1995: [[Pierre Billard]] (awarded vermeil medal for his work: ''L'Âge classique du cinéma français. Du cinéma parlant à la Nouvelle vague'') *1995: [[Jean-Michel Frodon]] (awarded vermeil medal for his work: ''L'Âge moderne du cinéma français. De la Nouvelle Vague à nos jours'') *1996: [[Edouard Molinaro]] *1997: [[Jacques Rozier]] *1998: [[Costa-Gavras]] *1999: [[Roman Polanski]] *2000: [[Patrice Leconte]] *2001: [[Agnès Jaoui]] and [[Jean-Pierre Bacri]] *2002: [[Agnès Varda]] *2003: [[André Téchiné]] *2004: [[Alain Corneau]] *2005: [[Claude Chabrol]] *2009: [[Agnès Varda]] *2010: [[Xavier Giannoli]] *2011: [[Danièle Thompson]] *2012: [[Benoît Jacquot]] *2013: [[Philippe Le Guay]] *2014: [[Robert Guédiguian]] *2015: [[Jacques Perrin]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://bibliobs.nouvelobs.com/sur-le-sentier-des-prix/20150626.OBS1590/prix-litteraires-l-academie-francaise-recompense-63-auteurs-d-un-coup.html|title=Prix littéraires : l'Académie française récompense 63 auteurs d'un coup |date=26 June 2015 |work=[[Le Nouvel Observateur]]}}</ref>

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=July 2018}} The '''Original SWAT World Challenge''' is an annual competition of law enforcement [[SWAT]] teams. It is usually held close to [[Little Rock, Arkansas]], USA and its goals are to encourage exchange of ideas/techniques and promote the high level of tactical skills, mental focus and physical endurance possessed by SWAT Teams.
== History ==
The event began in 2004 under its original name of World SWAT Challenge and was won by San Antonio, Texas. In 2005, Germany's [[GSG 9]] won all eight events and in 2006 won four of the eight events maintaining its top SWAT World Challenge ranking. The event was renamed Original SWAT World Challenge in 2005 when the tactical footwear company Original SWAT became title sponsor, and has since been expanded into the World SWAT Series which will include regional competitions capable of hosting 25-30 competing teams. The first of these was the Northeastern SWAT Challenge in late 2006, followed in 2007 by the addition of the Rocky Mountain Tactical Challenge, and a Mid-Western SWAT Challenge in 2008. These regional events follow the same format of the OSWC but with six events rather than eight, and are not limited to thirty teams.
[[OLN]] televised the 2007 event which was held 24–28 April close to Little Rock, Arkansas at [[Camp Joseph T. Robinson]] ([[United States National Guard|National Guard]] Base). This could become the regular venue for the competition. Original SWAT Footwear Company has discontinued its sponsorship of the event, and is now the title sponsor of the 2008 Original SWAT Tactical World Cup.
== Events == {{Expand section|date=January 2007}} #Zodiac Attack #Scott Entry Problem #Leopard Challenge #Glock Pistol Shoot Off #Sniper Challenge #Vehicle Assault #3 Gun Challenge #Original SWAT Rage Run
== Ranking ==
These are the current rankings of the competing teams as of 2007.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.swatseries.com/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2006-05-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20110716171629/http://www.swatseries.com/ |archivedate=16 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Most are designated from their city/state or country of origin.
